H0.text: A hard metal case with flexible foam lining is the best case to protect the several bird eggs a scientist wants to collect on an island.

H1.text: A flexible metal case with smooth plastic lining is the best case to protect several bird eggs collected by a scientist on an island.

H2.text: A strong wooden case with lightweight plastic lining is the best case to protect the bird eggs a scientist wants to collect on an island.

H3.text: A lightweight wooden case with strong aluminum lining is the best case for protecting the bird eggs that a scientist wants to collect on an island.

A4.text: The loss of foam caused the Space Shuttle Columbia disaster.

A5.text: Once cured and cooled, the material maintains its shape and properties.

A6.text: According to the Columbia accident report, NASA officials found foam loss in over 80% of the 79 missions for which they have pictures.

A7.text: Any air pocket, dirt or an uncovered tiny spot can knock it off due to extreme conditions of liftoff.

A8.text: Crumple zones absorb and dissipate the force of a collision, displacing and diverting it away from the passenger compartment and reducing the negative acceleration impact force on the vehicle occupants.

A9.text: Passive safety to components of the vehicle (primarily airbags, seatbelts and the physical structure of the vehicle) that help to protect occupants during a crash.

A10.text: Bird eggshells are made of calcium carbonate with a 5% organic matrix. This resilient external surface prevents desiccation of the contents, limits mechanical damage, and protects against microbes, all while allowing the exchange of gas with the surrounding atmosphere.

A11.text: In Greater Ani Crotophaga major this vaterite coating is thought to act as a shock absorber, protecting the calcite shell from fracture during incubation, such as colliding with other eggs in the nest.
